ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Valuable skills about applied econometric methods.
Overview of many different areas metrics
Lots of econometric knowledge.
Almost every econometric skills that I have to know.
further understanding of OLS and MLE; first time I learned about GMM; first time I had seen theoretical treatment of non-parametric statistics
I feel like my understanding of econometrics is greatly improved. Topics which I had no experience previously (e.g., time-series, nonparametric, etc) I feel like I understand well now.
MLE, GMM, and other important econometric tools.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Teach some extra topics at end so students aware of topics but do not include them on the final so that attention isn't diverted from the key topics.
Very practical. Lectures were a bit fast. Lots of algebra that could have used more examples or context.

I thought the topics we covered were generally very useful, and followed a logical order. Some of the problem sets were quite good, though others, particularly those in the second half of the course (e.g. the LDV ones) were perhaps too difficult, I think simpler problems would have been better for facilitating student learning.
Strengths: combination of theory and application in R or Stata; the Hansen textbook was great Weakness: presentation could be improved by uploading slides

The Hansen textbook is very useful and the class worked best when the lecture closely mirrored the textbook. I found Professor Armstrong's posted class notes extremely dense and confusing. When material was difficult in class, reading Hansen usually solved the problem. But, this solution did not work when class material was not covered in Hansen's text. I thought we covered an impressive amount of material over the course of the semester.
I hope the lecturer can spend some time on the motivations, transitions, and big pictures about different parts. Otherwise, it is very likely to get lost in Mathematics.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would.
Definitely for anyone conducting applied research
Necessary for economics.
Sure.
Yes

I would recommend it if one wants to learn econometrics fully. However, there are certain topics, such as GMM, which are discussed extensively but may have limited applications to fields outside of applied econometrics.
The methods it introduces is quite important and useful for empirical research.
